title: Marc Benioff
content:
{{Short description|American businessman (born 1964)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2019}} {{use American English|date=May 2021}} {{Infobox person | name = Marc Benioff | image = Marc Benioff.jpg | caption = Benioff in 2021 | birth_name = Marc Russell Benioff | birth_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], U.S. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|9|25}} | spouse = Lynne Krilich | children = 2 | known_for = Founder, chairman and CEO, [[Salesforce]]
Co-chair and owner, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{cite web|url=https://time.com/6102640/jane-goodall-environment-hope/|title=The Enduring Hope of Jane Goodall |website=time.com|date=September 30, 2021 |access-date=March 30, 2022}} | education = [[University of Southern California]] (BS) }} '''Marc Russell Benioff''' (born September 25, 1964){{Cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n2009036451|title=Benioff, Marc R. 1964- [WorldCat Identities]}} is an American [[internet entrepreneur]] and philanthropist. Benioff is best known as the co-founder, chairman and CEO of the software company [[Salesforce]], as well as being the owner of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine since 2018.{{Cite web |title=Marc Benioff |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/marc-benioff/ |access-date=December 30, 2018 |website=Forbes |language=en}} == Early life and education == Marc Russell Benioff was born on September 25, 1964, and raised in a Jewish family[https://www.jpost.com/jewish-world/jewish-news/jews-take-5-of-top-6-spots-in-annual-list-of-top-us-givers Jerusalem Post: "Jews take 5 of top 6 spots in annual list of top US givers" By JACOB BERKMAN] February 9, 2011[http://ejewishphilanthropy.com/jewish-philanthropy-2-0/ Jewish Philanthropy: "Jewish Philanthropy 2.0"] February 23, 2011 in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. He is the grandson of Marvin Lewis, a California trial attorney and once-time member of the San Francisco [[San Francisco Board of Supervisors|Board of Supervisors]] who championed the creation of the [[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]] system.{{cite web | url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/oursf/article/Before-Marc-Benioff-blazed-trails-grandfather-14516074.php | title=Marc Benioff, Salesforce, and the monorail-loving SF supervisor who inspired them | date=October 15, 2019 }}{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/obituaries/marvin-e-lewis-84-a-pioneering-lawyer.html | title=Marvin e. Lewis, 84, A Pioneering Lawyer | work=The New York Times | date=October 7, 1991 }} Benioff grew up in [[Hillsborough, California|Hillsborough]]{{cite web | url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Russell-Benioff-owner-of-apparel-chain-dies-2575946.php | title=Russell Benioff, owner of apparel chain, dies | date=January 17, 2012 }} and graduated from [[Burlingame High School (California)|Burlingame High School]] in 1982.{{Cite news |last=Newton |first=Casey |author-link=Casey Newton |date=July 24, 2011 |title=Marc Benioff, CEO, makes philanthropy a priority |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Marc-Benioff-CEO-makes-philanthropy-a-priority-2353592.php |work=[[SFGate]]}} Benioff received a Bachelor of Science in [[business administration]] from the [[University of Southern California]], where he was a member of the [[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity]], in 1986.{{Cite web |last=Lynley |first=Matt |title=Frat Boys Are Taking Over The Tech World |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/frat-boys-are-taking-over-the-tech-world-2012-2 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} Benioff is a second cousin of [[showrunner]] and television writer [[David Benioff]], known for ''[[Game of Thrones]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-these-famous-benioffs-are-related-2015-4|title=How these famous Benioffs are related |first=Julie |last=Bort |date=April 12, 2015 |work=[[Business Insider]] |access-date=March 28, 2016}} He is married to Lynne Benioff and has two children. The family lives in San Francisco, California. == Career == While in high school, Benioff sold his first application, How to Juggle, for $75. In 1979, when he was 15, Benioff founded Liberty Software, creating and selling games such as ''Flapper'' and ''King Arthur's Heir'' for the [[Atari 8-bit]].{{Cite magazine |last=Duberman |first=David |date=January 1984 |title=ROM Fun: Survey of recent cartridge games |url=https://archive.org/details/1984-01-anticmagazine |magazine=Antic |pages=[https://archive.org/details/1984-01-anticmagazine/page/n61 62]–63}}{{Cite web |last=Bort |first=Julie |title=The Fabulous Life Of Tech Billionaire Marc Benioff |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/the-fab-life-of-billionaire-marc-benioff-2014-2 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} Royalties from these games helped Benioff pay for college.{{cite book |author1=Benioff, Marc |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XX5QJ7hfDW8C&pg=PR18 |title=Behind the Cloud: The Untold Story of How Salesforce.com Went from Idea to Billion-Dollar Company-and Revolutionized an Industry |author2=Adler, Carlyle |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-470-53592-9 |pages=xviii–xx |author-link=Marc Benioff}} While at [[University of Southern California|USC]], Benioff had an internship as a programmer at [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] where he wrote [[assembly code]] for the [[Macintosh 128K|Macintosh]].{{Cite web |last=Farber |first=Dan |date=September 10, 2013 |title=Marc Benioff explains Steve Jobs' spirituality and chides Apple |url=https://www.cnet.com/tech/tech-industry/marc-benioff-explains-steve-jobs-spirituality-and-chides-apple/ |website=CNET}}{{Cite web |last=Sauer |first=Megan |date=2022-02-22 |title=A teenage Marc Benioff cold-called an Apple executive — and got his dream internship |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/02/22/salesforces-marc-benioff-what-i-learned-as-a-teenaged-apple-intern.html |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=CNBC |language=en}} He joined [[Oracle Corporation]] in a customer-service role after graduating. Benioff worked at Oracle for 13 years in a variety of sales, marketing, and product development roles. At 23, he was named Oracle's Rookie of the Year. Three years later, he became the youngest person in the company's history to earn the title of vice president. Benioff founded [[Salesforce]] in 1999{{Cite web |title=The stratospheric rise of Marc Benioff and Salesforce |url=https://fortune.com/longform/marc-benioff-salesforce-slack-acquisition-diversity-inclusion-fortune-500/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Fortune |language=en}} in a San Francisco apartment and defined its mission in a marketing statement as "The End of Software."[https://www.salesforce.com/blog/2013/03/how-to-turn-a-simple-idea-into-a-high-growth-company.html Salesforce Blog: "Marc Benioff: How to Turn a Simple Idea into a High-Growth Company" By Marc Benioff] March 8, 2013 This was a slogan he used frequently to preach about software on the Web, and used as a guerilla marketing tactic against the dominant CD-ROM CRM competitor [[Siebel Systems|Siebel]] at the time.{{Cite web|date=2020-12-06|title=The Marketing Genius of Marc Benioff|url=https://viralwegrow.com/blog/evolving-fashion-marc-benioffs-marketing-genius/|access-date=2020-12-07|website=ViralWeGrow|language=en}} Benioff extended Salesforce's offerings in the early 2000s with the idea of a platform that allowed developers to create applications.{{Cite web |title=The story of why Marc Benioff gifted the AppStore.com domain to Steve Jobs |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2020/01/02/the-story-of-why-marc-benioff-gifted-the-appstore-com-domain-to-steve-jobs/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}} Salesforce is now the biggest employer in San Francisco and the anchor tenant of [[Salesforce Tower]], the tallest building in San Francisco.{{Cite web |last=Wehner |first=Greg |date=2023-07-16 |title=San Francisco's downtown 'never going back to the way it was,' Salesforce's Marc Benioff says |url=https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/san-franciscos-downtown-never-back-way-salesforces-marc-benioff |access-date=2024-02-07 |website=FOXBusiness |language=en-US}} Benioff also serves on the World Economic Forum's board of trustees and USC board of trustees.{{Cite web |last=Rogers |first=Matt Weinberger, Taylor Nicole |title=The rise of Marc Benioff, the bombastic owner of Time Magazine who just became Salesforce's sole CEO, has an $8 billion fortune, and owns a 5-acre compound in Hawaii |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/the-rise-of-salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-2016-3 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} On September 16, 2018, Marc and his wife Lynne bought ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' for $190 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/16/business/dealbook/time-magazine-salesforce-marc-benioff.html|title=Time Magazine Is Bought by Marc Benioff, Salesforce Billionaire|newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 16, 2018|language=en-GB|last1=Chozick |first1=Amy |last2=Gelles |first2=David }} In 2019, Benioff started Time Ventures, a venture capital fund that has invested in multiple companies, including [[Commonwealth Fusion Systems]], Universal Hydrogen and NCX.{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/nuclear-fusion-startup-lands-1-8-billion-as-investors-chase-star-power-11638334801 | title=WSJ News Exclusive | Nuclear-Fusion Startup Lands $1.8 Billion as Investors Chase Star Power | newspaper=Wall Street Journal | date=December 2021 | last1=Hiller | first1=Jennifer }}{{cite web | url=https://www.thestreet.com/investing/commonwealth-fusion-secures-big-investment-round | title=Commonwealth Fusion, Backed by Gates, Soros, Benioff, Raises $1.8B | date=December 2021 }}{{cite web | url=https://venturebeat.com/entrepreneur/ncx-raises-50m-for-natural-capital-markets/ | title=NCX raises $50M for natural capital markets | date=March 2, 2022 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/03/02/marc-benioff-backs-ncx-start-up-using-satellites-to-count-trees-.html | title=Marc Benioff backs start-up that uses satellites to count trees and pays people not to cut them down | website=[[CNBC]] | date=March 2, 2022 }}{{cite web | url=https://labusinessjournal.com/technology/universal-hydrogen-raises-62-million-series-b/ | title=Universal Hydrogen Raises $62 Million in Series B | date=October 14, 2021 }} In 2021, two companies Time Venture backed, Planet Labs and IonQ, went public.{{cite web | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/07/space-co-planet-labs-going-public-backed-by-google-blackrock-benioff.html | title=Satellite imagery company Planet Labs is going public, backed by Google, BlackRock and Marc Benioff | website=[[CNBC]] | date=July 7, 2021 }}{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/planet-labs-looks-to-expand-software-offerings-win-new-customers-with-ipo-funds-11638181801 | title=Planet Labs Looks to Expand Software Offerings, Win New Customers with IPO Funds | newspaper=Wall Street Journal | date=November 29, 2021 | last1=Maurer | first1=Mark }}{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/moorinsights/2021/03/23/ionq-takes-quantum-computing-public-with-a-2-billion-deal/ | title=IonQ Takes Quantum Computing Public with A $2 Billion Deal | website=[[Forbes]] }} Benioff is a member of Business Roundtable, an advocacy group of CEOs, and the Business Council.{{cite web | url=https://www.crainsdetroit.com/news/top-execs-discuss-mission-thats-above-profits-detroit-event | title=Top execs discuss 'mission that's above profits' in Detroit event | date=October 4, 2018 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/17/success/salesforce-marc-benioff-boss-files/index.html | title=Marc Benioff says CEOs must be held more accountable — and pay more taxes, too | CNN Business | website=[[CNN]] | date=October 17, 2019 }} In November 2021, Benioff became co-CEO of Salesforce when Bret Taylor's promotion to co-CEO was announced.{{cite web | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/30/salesforce-promotes-bret-taylor-to-co-ceo.html | title=Salesforce promotes Bret Taylor to co-CEO alongside Benioff | website=[[CNBC]] | date=November 30, 2021 }} One year later, Bret Taylor stepped down as Salesforce co-CEO, leaving Marc Benioff as the sole CEO again.{{cite web | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/11/30/bret-taylor-steps-down-as-co-ceo-of-salesforce-marc-benioff-stays-on-as-ceo.html | title=Bret Taylor steps down as Salesforce co-CEO | website=[[CNBC]] | date=November 30, 2022 }} As of February 2022, Benioff had an estimated net worth of US$8.31 billion according to ''[[Bloomberg Billionaires Index]]''.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/profiles/marc-r-benioff|newspaper=Bloomberg.com|access-date=January 12, 2023|title=Bloomberg Billionaires Index}} A 2024 investigation by [[National Public Radio|NPR]] journalist Dara Kerr found that Benioff has purchased more than 600 acres of land in [[Hawaii]], mostly near the town of [[Waimea, Hawaii County, Hawaii|Waimea]] on [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]]. Benioff's purchases, which totaled $24.5 million as of February 2024, have sparked concern among Waimea locals regarding [[Hawaii#Cost_of_living|rising housing prices]].{{cite news |last1=Kerr |first1=Dara |title=A tech billionaire is quietly buying up land in Hawaii. No one knows why |url=https://www.npr.org/2024/02/28/1232564250/billionaire-benioff-buys-hawaii-land-salesforce?ft=nprml&f=1006 |access-date=28 Feb 2024 |agency=National Public Radio |date=28 Feb 2024}} === Co-written work === Benioff has co-written four books about business and technology. In 2004, he co-wrote ''Compassionate Capitalism: How Corporations Can Make Doing Good an Integral Part of Doing Well'' with Karen Southwick.{{Cite web |date=2021-10-20 |title=The goodness business: how woke capitalism turned virtue into profit |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/long-reads/2021/10/the-goodness-business-how-woke-capitalism-turned-virtue-into-profit |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=New Statesman |language=en-US}} In 2006, he co-wrote ''The Business of Changing the World: 20 Great Leaders on Strategic Corporate Philanthropy'' with Carlye Adler. In 2009, he co-wrote ''Behind the Cloud: The Untold Story of How Salesforce.com Went from Idea to Billion-Dollar Company and Revolutionized an Industry'', also with Carlye Adler.{{Cite web |last=Kim |first=Eugene |title=Billionaire CEO Marc Benioff is writing a sequel to his best-selling memoir about Salesforce — and wants your help |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-is-writing-a-new-book-2016-1 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} In 2019, he again co-wrote ''Trailblazer: The Power of Business as the Greatest Platform for Change'', with [[Monica Langley]]. The book became a [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' bestseller]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2019/11/17/business-books/|website=New York Times|title=Books|date=November 15, 2018}} == Recognition == [[File:Marc R. Benioff World Economic Forum 2013.jpg|thumb|Benioff during the [[World Economic Forum|WEF]] 2013]]In 2003, President [[George W. Bush]] appointed Benioff co-chair of the President's Information Technology Advisory Committee.{{Cite web |last=Feloni |first=Richard |title=Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff explains why a Hindu guru and Colin Powell were critical mentors |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/marc-benioff-colin-powell-advice-salesforce-2016-3 |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} In 2009, Benioff was named a Young Global Leader by the [[World Economic Forum]], and is a member of its board of trustees.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/02/25/world-economic-forum-announces-new-batch-of-young-global-leaders-mark-zuckerberg-chad-hurley-kevin-rose-and-more/|title=World Economic Forum Announces New Batch Of Young Global Leaders (Mark Zuckerberg, Chad Hurley, Kevin Rose And More)|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|language=en-US|date=February 25, 2009}}{{Cite news |date=2022-01-13 |title=C.E.O.s Were Our Heroes, at Least According to Them |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/13/business/davos-man-marc-benioff-book.html |access-date=2022-03-30 |issn=0362-4331}} In 2012, he was named one of the "Best CEOs in the World" by ''[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron]]''{{'}}s[http://www.barrons.com/articles/SB50001424053111904797004577283662192414888 Barron's: "World's Best CEOs" By Andrew Bary] March 26, 2012 and received ''[[The Economist]]''{{'}}s Innovation Award.[https://www.economist.com/news/technology-quarterly/21567206-innovation-awards-our-annual-prizes-recognise-successful-innovators-eight The Economist: "And the winners were..." By The Economist Staff] December 1, 2012 In 2014, ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' readers voted him "Businessperson of the Year."[http://fortune.com/2014/11/12/businessperson-year-readers-choice/ Fortune: "Vote: Businessperson of the Year - Championship Round" By Fortune Editors] November 12, 2014 In 2016, ''Fortune'' named him one of the "World's 50 Greatest Leaders."[http://fortune.com/2016/03/24/worlds-greatest-leaders-2016-intro/ Fortune: "The World's 50 Greatest Leaders" By Geoff Colvin] March 25, 2016 In 2019, he was recognized as one of the 10 Best-Performing CEOs by ''[[Harvard Business Review]]''{{cite journal|url=https://hbr.org/2019/11/the-best-performing-ceos-in-the-world-2019|journal=Harvard Business Review|title=The Best-Performing CEOs in the World, 2019|date=November 2019 }} and as the CNN Business CEO of 2020.{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/23/investing/marc-benioff-salesforce-ceo-of-year/index.html|website=CNN|title=Marc Benioff of Salesforce is the CNN Business CEO of 2020 |date=December 23, 2020 }} == Philanthropy == [[File:Marc Benioff in 2009.jpg|thumb|Marc Benioff in 2009]]In addition to founding Salesforce in 1999, Benioff also founded the Salesforce Foundation. The foundation uses a "1-1-1" approach to corporate philanthropy, where the company gives one percent of employee time as volunteer hours, one percent of its product and one percent of its revenue to charitable causes.{{cite web | url=https://fortune.com/longform/marc-benioff-salesforce-slack-acquisition-diversity-inclusion-fortune-500/ | title=The stratospheric rise of Marc Benioff and Salesforce }}{{cite web | url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/320186 | title=Marc Benioff Reached Millionaire Status by Age 25 -- and 9 Other Things to Know About the Co-Founder of Salesforce | date=September 17, 2018 }}{{cite web |date=July 26, 2014 |title=Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff: The big giver |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-the-big-giver/ |publisher=[[CNET]]}} In 2010, the Benioffs donated $100 million to [[UCSF Benioff Children's Hospital|UCSF Children's Hospital]]. In 2014, they donated an additional $100 million to the hospital and $50 million to fund research on premature birth. In 2019, the Benioffs donated $25 million to UCSF to create the UCSF Benioff Center for Microbiome Medicine; $10 million to [[Stanford University]] for the Microbiome Therapies Initiative;{{cite web | url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/health/article/Gut-check-Benioffs-donate-35-million-to-further-14299322.php | title=Gut check: Benioffs donate $35 million to further study of microbiome at UCSF, Stanford | date=August 13, 2019 }} and $35 million to establish a Prostate Cancer Research Initiative at [[University of California, San Francisco]].{{cite news|url=https://philanthropynewsdigest.org/news/benioffs-give-35-million-for-ucsf-prostate-cancer-research-initiative |title=Benioffs Give $35 Million for UCSF Prostate Cancer Research Initiative|date=September 20, 2019|work=Philanthropy News Digest|access-date=March 12, 2023}} In 2016, Benioff announced a $10 million donation to the [[University of California at Santa Barbara]] to establish the Benioff Ocean Initiative.{{cite web | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/15/benioffs-new-philanthropic-mission-oceans/90415540/ | title=Benioff's new philanthropic mission: The oceans | website=[[USA Today]] }} In 2017, the Benioffs partnered with the [[National Fish and Wildlife Foundation|US National Fish and Wildlife Foundation]] and the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] to form the Pacific Islands Research and Conservation Programme.{{cite web | url=https://www.computerweekly.com/news/252508761/Benioffs-and-Salesforce-put-300m-into-combating-climate-change-on-eve-of-COP26 | title=Benioffs and Salesforce put $300m into combating climate change on eve of COP26 | Computer Weekly }} In 2019, the Benioffs donated $30 million to the Center for Vulnerable Populations for the [[Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative]] to study the impacts of homelessness, housing, and health.{{Cite web |title=UCSF Launches New Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative with $30M Gift |url=https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2019/05/414316/ucsf-launches-new-benioff-homelessness-and-housing-initiative-30m-gift |website=UCSF Launches New Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative with $30M Gift | UC San Francisco|date=May 2019 }} In January 2020, Benioff announced that he and his wife would provide financial backing for 1t.org to support a global initiative to plant and conserve 1 trillion trees over the next decade.{{cite web | url=https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/1/21/21075804/marc-benioff-trees-silicon-valley-donald-trump-davos | title=Marc Benioff picks a new fight with Silicon Valley — over trees | date=January 21, 2020 }} In March 2020, Benioff procured 50 million pieces of personal protective equipment for hospitals and [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19]] first responders in the United States.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/28/business/coronavirus-marc-benioff-salesforce.html | title=Marc Benioff's $25 Million Blitz to Buy Protective Gear from China | work=The New York Times | date=April 28, 2020 | last1=Gelles | first1=David }} In April 2020, Benioff donated more than $1 million to Give2SF COVID-19 Response and Recovery Fund.{{cite web | url=https://sf.curbed.com/2020/4/30/21241539/sf-billionaires-donations-coronavirus-dorsey-benioff | title=San Francisco has 75 billionaires. Most of them aren't donating to local COVID-19 relief | date=April 30, 2020 }} In April 2021, Benioff and Salesforce sent a plane filled with medical supplies to India to help the country handle the COVID-19 pandemic.{{cite news | url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/tech-bytes/salesforce-to-send-plane-load-of-medical-supplies-to-india-founder-marc-benioff/articleshow/82305595.cms | title=Salesforce to send plane load of medical supplies to India: Founder Marc Benioff | newspaper=The Economic Times }} In October 2020, Marc and Lynne Benioff were founding partners of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]]'s [[Earthshot prize|Earthshot Prize]], a program for finding solutions to environmental issues.{{Cite web |title='Next 10 years are critical': Prince William backs £50m climate change project Earthshots |url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/europe/next-10-years-are-critical-prince-william-backs-50m-climate-change-project-earthshots-1.1090175 |access-date=2020-10-13 |website=The National |date=October 8, 2020 |language=en}} In October 2021, Benioff pledged a $200 million donation to plant trees and fund ecologically focused entrepreneurs.{{Cite web |last=Dolan |first=Kerry A. |title=Salesforce Billionaire Marc Benioff Pledges $200 Million For Reforestation, Climate Entrepreneurs |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kerryadolan/2021/10/28/salesforce-billionaire-marc-benioff-pledges-200-million-for-reforestation-climate-entrepreneurs/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Forbes |language=en}} Salesforce also donated $100 million to the same causes.{{Cite web |title=Marc and Lynne Benioff, Salesforce donate $300M to encourage climate action |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2021/10/28/marc-and-lynne-benioff-salesforce-donate-300m-to-encourage-climate-action/ |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=TechCrunch |date=October 28, 2021 |language=en-US}} In 2021, they were founding members of the World Economic Forum's Friends of Ocean Action initiative, providing approximately $11 million in funding. Marc and Lynne Benioff have been included in lists of top givers by ''[[Forbes]]'' and the ''[[The Chronicle of Philanthropy|Chronicle of Philanthropy]]''.{{cite web |title=America's Top Givers of 2016 |url=https://www.forbes.com/top-givers/ |access-date=September 19, 2018 |website=Forbes}}{{cite web |date=February 6, 2011 |title=No. 10 (tied): Marc R. and Lynne Benioff |url=https://philanthropy.com/article/No-10-tied-Marc-R-and/159141 |access-date=September 19, 2018 |website=philanthropy.com}}[https://philanthropy.com/article/Young-Tech-Donors-Take-Leading/151779 The Chronicle of Philanthropy: "Young Tech Donors Take Leading Role in Philanthropy 50" By Alex Daniels and Maria Di Mento] February 8, 2015[https://philanthropy.com/article/Conservative-Billionaire/235234 The Chronicle of Philanthropy: "Bequests Put Conservative Billionaire Richard Scaife Atop List of America's 50 Biggest Donors" By Maria Di Mento and Drew Lindsay] February 9, 2016 In 2024, the Benioffs donated a total of $150 million towards Hawaii hospitals that will link [[Hawaii Pacific Health]] system (HPH) with Hilo Medical Center (HMC) and the UCSF Health. $100 million will be used toward the redevelopment of the new Straub Hospital campus in Honolulu, part of HPH, slated for completion in 2026; $50 million will go towards revamping the aging Hilo Medical Center on the Hawaii island. HPH intends to collaborate with HMC in physician co-recruitment efforts on the Hawaii island, while UCSF Health, specifically and [[UCSF Benioff Children's Hospital|UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospitals]], will provide clinical expertise outreach efforts in  oncology and neurology for patients needing specialized care at these Hawaii facilities. Both Straub and HMC will rename their hospitals to Straub Benioff Medical Center and Hilo Benioff Medical Center, respectively, in recognition of the Benioffs.{{Cite web |last=Wu |first=Nina |date=2024-03-05 |title=Marc and Lynne Benioff donate $150M to 2 Hawaii hospitals |url=https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/03/05/hawaii-news/marc-and-lynne-benioff-donate-150m-to-2-hawaii-hospitals/ |access-date=2024-03-05 |website=Honolulu Star-Advertiser |language=en-US}} == Social activism == ===Abortion=== In September 2021, Benioff announced that Salesforce would relocate any Texas employees who wanted to move after an [[Texas Heartbeat Act|abortion law]] went into effect.{{Cite web |date=2021-09-11 |title=Salesforce to help workers leave states over abortion laws |url=https://apnews.com/article/technology-business-texas-greg-abbott-marc-benioff-98094859a011193d3c83d6a4ff1e7a8a |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=AP NEWS |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Novet |first=Jordan |date=2021-09-11 |title=Salesforce offers to relocate employees and their families after Texas abortion law goes into effect |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/09/10/salesforce-offers-to-relocate-employees-from-texas-after-abortion-bill.html |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=CNBC |language=en}} ===LGBTQ issues=== In March 2015, Benioff announced Salesforce would cancel all employee programs and travel in the state of Indiana after the passing of the [[Religious Freedom Restoration Act (Indiana)|Religious Freedom Restoration Act]], a bill that would allow companies and individuals to choose not to serve LGBT individuals based on religious beliefs.[http://www.ibj.com/articles/52427-salesforce-ceo-were-cancelling-travel-to-indiana Indiana Business Journal: "Salesforce CEO: We're canceling travel to Indiana" By Jared Council] March 26, 2015 Benioff led an effort of business leaders fighting back against the legislation, leading to a revised version of the bill being signed into law that prohibited businesses from denying services to someone based on sexual orientation or gender identity.[https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/07/marc-benioff-indiana_n_7017032.html The Huffington Post: "The CEO Who Took On Indiana's Anti-LGBT Law — And Won" By Alexander C. Kaufman] April 7, 2015 In February 2016, Benioff announced that Salesforce would reduce investments in Georgia and cancel a conference if HB 757, a bill that would allow businesses to decline services to same-sex couples, was passed.[http://fortune.com/2016/02/26/salesforce-marc-benioff-georgia-gay-marriage/ Fortune: "Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff Battles Georgia Over Gay Rights" By Jonathan Vanian] February 26, 2016 The governor vetoed the bill.[http://politics.blog.ajc.com/2016/03/28/breaking-nathan-deal-will-veto-georgias-religious-liberty-bill/ Atlanta Journal-Constitution: "BREAKING: Nathan Deal vetoes Georgia's 'religious liberty' bill" By Greg Bluestein] April 9, 2016 ===Gender pay gap=== In April 2015, after the issue was raised by Salesforce chief personnel officer Cindy Robbins, Benioff announced that he would review salaries at Salesforce to ensure men and women were paid equally.[https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/23/salesforce-pay-gap_n_7126892.html The Huffington Post: "Salesforce CEO Takes Radical Step To Pay Men And Women Equally" By Emily Peck] April 23, 2015 He subsequently dedicated $3 million in 2015 to correct the discrepancy, and another $3 million in 2017 to “correct compensation differences by gender, race, and ethnicity across the company”.{{cite web |last1=Schwantes |first1=Marcel |title=The CEO of Salesforce Found Out His Female Employees Were Paid Less Than Men. His Response Is a Priceless Leadership Lesson |url=https://www.inc.com/marcel-schwantes/the-ceo-of-salesforce-found-out-female-employees-are-paid-less-than-men-his-response-is-a-priceless-leadership-lesson.html |website=Inc}} ===Homelessness in San Francisco=== In an October 2018 interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'', Benioff criticized other technology industry executives for "hoarding" their money and refusing to help [[Homelessness|the homeless]] in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].{{Cite news |last=Levin |first=Sam |date=October 17, 2018 |title=Salesforce CEO: tech billionaires 'hoard their money' and won't help homeless |newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/oct/17/salesforce-ceo-marc-benioff-san-francisco-homeless-interview |via=www.theguardian.com}} In November, Benioff announced his support for [[Homelessness in the San Francisco Bay Area#Proposition C|San Francisco's Prop C measure]] that would increase taxes on large corporations to aid unhoused residents in the city.{{Cite web |last=Ghaffary |first=Shirin |date=2018-11-14 |title=Marc Benioff says he had rabbis and imams supporting the Prop C homelessness tax — but not tech CEOs |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/11/14/18093170/marc-benioff-homeless-tax-prop-c-tech-ceos |access-date=2022-03-30 |website=Vox |language=en}} In July 2023, Benioff stated that San Francisco "will never go back to the way it was before the pandemic" and recommended that city leadership convert old office space into housing and hire more police. In an interview held in August, he threatened to pull Salesforce’s annual Dreamforce conference from the city if the 2023 event were disrupted.{{cite web |last1=Li |first1=Dominic Fracassa, Roland |title=Dreamforce to return to San Francisco in 2024 — despite threats to leave |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/sf/article/dreamforce-conference-san-francisco-salesforce-18475195.php |website=San Francisco Chronicle |language=en}}{{cite web |last1=Fagan |first1=Roland Li, Kevin |title=Marc Benioff: Next month's Dreamforce could be last in S.F. if it's affected by homelessness, drug use |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/sf/article/marc-benioff-dreamforce-could-leave-s-f-18337259.php |website=San Francisco Chronicle |language=en}} He used his platform on X to call for “refunding the police” numerous times between September and November 2023.{{cite web |last1=Benioff |first1=Marc |url=https://twitter.com/Benioff/status/1718761249930989941 |website=X}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==
